text: We will hear arguments first today in the case of the United States against Ross.

Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, this case is here on a writ of certiorari for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which reversed Respondent's conviction on the ground that certain evidence should have been suppressed.

Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, on behalf of the Respondent, our position is succinctly that the circuit court was correct in invalidating the search in this case, and that the circuit court's opinion has been reinforced by this Court's judgment in Robbins versus California.

Justice Stevens asked my colleague about lifting up a blanket that might be covering some items in the back of the car, and I think this touches upon the point which, as far as I am aware, is the only substantive argument of policy advanced for requiring warrants for searching insubstantial containers, and that is the bright line test, argument.
